ygData.subject: Re: Cure Blindness
ygData.msgSnippet: One thing about using cancel magic is that you can only cancel the spells of those casters that are at your lvl or below also you cant have buffs if you take
ygData.messageBody:
One thing about using cancel magic is that you can only cancel the spells of
those casters that are at your lvl or below also you cant have buffs if you
take this root because cancel magic will cancel the buffs first (older
spells ---> newer spells is the order in which it will cancel) but with cure
blindness I ahve cured myself when i was blinded by a red muddites so you
see where cure comes in good:) Also I have had only to cast it once to get
rid of it nonlike some poisons which can take up to three cast.

-----Original Message-----
From: Olli Haapam∩┐╜ki <olli.haapamaki@...>
To: EQ-Clerics@onelist.com <EQ-Clerics@onelist.com>
Date: Monday, June 07, 1999 4:43 AM
Subject: Re: [EQ-Clerics] Cure Blindness


>From: Olli Haapam∩┐╜ki <olli.haapamaki@...>
>
>> Go fight muddites in beholder. You'll find a pretty damn good use for
>cure blindness real quick. Not to mention any other time one of your
>party members gets blinded. Or.. If you yourself get blinded while
>soloing it kinda puts a kink in your gameplan. Not being able to see
>what's going on can cost you your life. As with a few other cure
>spells, it sometimes has to be cast more than once to be effective. <
>
>I have been using Cancel Magic effectively against the blindness that the
Muddites cause. I have one question: Is it significantly faster to cast a
Cure Blindness than Cancel Magic? I know cancel magic uses 50% more mana but
it is so little anyway (20 -> 30) that there is no point in purchasing the
spell just for that. Besides the cancel magic works for a wider variety of
things. Very useful when you are rooted, isn't it? Is there anything that
could cause blindness and that cancel magic could not cure?
>
>------------------------------------------------------------------------
>Where do some of the Internet's largest email lists reside?
>http://www.onelist.com
>At ONElist - the most scalable and reliable service on the Internet.
>
